Description: OAPEC imposed an oil embargo on nations supporting Israel in the Yom Kippur War, quadrupling oil prices from $3 to $12 per barrel.
The revolution disrupted Iran's oil production, causing a supply shortage and doubling oil prices to over $30 per barrel.
The war reduced oil output from Iran and Iraq, leading to price spikes and global supply concerns.
OPEC increased production to regain market share, causing a supply glut and a 50% price drop to around $10 per barrel.
Iraq’s invasion of Kuwait disrupted oil supplies, causing prices to double to $40 per barrel before stabilizing.
Economic collapse in Asia reduced oil demand, leading to a price drop to below $15 per barrel.
The U.S. invasion of Iraq disrupted oil exports, causing price volatility and a rise to $35 per barrel.
Global demand collapsed after Lehman Brothers’ bankruptcy, causing oil prices to plummet from $145 to $32 per barrel.
Uprisings in Libya and Egypt disrupted oil production, pushing prices above $100 per barrel.
OPEC maintained production levels despite a supply glut, leading to a price collapse from $110 to below $50 per barrel.
OPEC and non-OPEC members agreed to cut production by 1.8 million barrels per day, stabilizing prices around $50 per barrel.
Global demand fell due to the pandemic; a Russia-Saudi price war caused prices to drop to negative levels in April.
Russia rejected OPEC’s proposed cuts, prompting Saudi Arabia to slash prices, leading to a 65% oil price drop.
Russia’s invasion and Western sanctions on Russian oil caused prices to spike to $120 per barrel.
OPEC+ announced voluntary cuts of 1.65 million barrels per day, pushing prices to $87 per barrel before declining.
